history.content: Getting a research offer can sometimes be more rewarding than an industry internship. It can depend on what you want to do after college. However this is something that you can put on your resume. REU programs are competitive, and it will look very good. In addition, it gives you an opportunity to get strong recommendation letters that will help you find internships (or more research opportunities if this experience makes you decide you want to go into research). REU programs are really good for if you are looking to go to grad school too. In my opinion, getting research experience looks really good, if not better than some industry internships. In addition, in my experience, having that research experience made it easier to have intellectual conversations with professors during office hours. But if that does not convince you, having something over the summer is better than not.

children.subject: How do you get a summer research ?
I am graduating in fall 2018. Is it not possible for me to apply for internship for summer 2018?

I'm a fellow transfer student too! Also graduating in 2018. 

I'm not 100% sure. I thought you needed at least another semester after the summer to do an internship. Hopefully somone can come by and answer.
Well, fall 2018 is exactly one semester after summer 2018. I believe I could apply for internships, but I also would like to have an answer for this.

Oh! Whoops I totally read that wrong. I assumed Spring 2018. 

I think you should be fine. And if you look at some well known companies websites, like Microsoft, it says as long as you have 1 quarter/semester after internship, you are eligible.
You definitely can!! Internships have different requirements. I have come across a few that say you need to be in school when you submit an application in order to be eligible.
Senior's can apply for internships for summer before they graduate? I thought you had to do full time.

history.content: I got a summer REU offer doing research in parallel computing, but I don't have any industry internship offer.  I am not sure if I should give up the research opportunity and keep looking for internships at local startups because I am leaning more toward industry after graduation. The research sounds very interesting and I will be learning things like MapReduce, Hadoop, HPC, etc. I am currently a junior (transfer) but plan to stay an extra semester, so I have next summer to do an internship before I graduate. Industry work experience seems to be more important than research when applying for internships, but I also do personal projects to make up for that. I would like to hear your suggestions and advice for this. Thank you.
history.subject: Internship vs. Summer REU
